I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed policy-
based loan to the Republic of Indonesia for subprogram 2 of the Financial Market Development 
and Inclusion Program.1 The report also describes the proposed technical assistance (TA) for 
Promoting Innovative Financial Inclusion, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting 
under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA.  
 
2.  The  proposed  subprogram  2  supports  the  government’s  main  reform  priorities  in 
developing and making the finance sector more inclusive, and represents a medium- to long-term 
partnership between the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the government, and the Financial 
Services Authority (OJK). The government’s priority areas include (i) strengthening the regulatory 
structure for financial stability, (ii) deepening the financial market, and (iii) enhancing financial 
inclusion with a focus on promoting access to financial services to poor households and women. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The programmatic approach and subprogram 1 policy-based loan were approved by the 
ADB Board of Directors on 1 September 2015. The program includes three subprograms aligned 
with the government’s strategy and critical finance sector reforms. The first subprogram focused 
on  establishing  the  OJK  as  a  unified  and  independent  financial  services  regulator  and 
implementing international best practices. Subprogram 2 focuses on support to the consolidated 
finance sector master plan and advancing OJK’s fiscal independence. Responding to government 
concerns of rising inequality and the recommendations from the 2016 National Financial Inclusion 
Strategy, subprograms 2 and 3 further expand ADB’s engagement in financial inclusion, with a 
focus on improving poor families’ access to financial services, financial literacy, and consumer 
protection. This provides the platform for a subsequent dedicated financial inclusion sector 
development program in 2020. The approach uses policy-based lending as it embeds the policy 
matrix within the government’s policy decision-making process. The loan proceeds provide 
incentives for reforms. The attached TA builds capacity of the government and the OJK.    
 
4.  Development problems. Indonesia is facing the twin problems of insufficient growth and 
rising household income inequality. Economic growth has steadily declined from 6.4% in 2010, 
and its average growth between 2014 and 2016 was approximately 5.0%. This is low compared 
to its medium-term growth rate, which averages 5.6%. Growth is expected to remain only slightly 
above 5.0% in 2017.2 This may not be sufficient to provide employment for the 3 million additional 
people who attain working age each year. While commodity prices have begun to recover, 
structural weaknesses in the economy, such as the low competitiveness of the real sector and 
inadequate investments in infrastructure, underlie this prolonged slowdown in economic growth. 
Indonesia needs new sources of growth to meet its ambitious economic growth target of 8.0% by 
2019. This requires acceleration in public and private infrastructure investments to improve 
economic competitiveness, investment climate, and inclusive financial intermediation.  
                                                
1  Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2015. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: 
Proposed Programmatic Approach and Policy-Based Loan to the Republic of Indonesia for Subprogram 1 of the 
Financial Market Development and Inclusion Program. Manila. 
2  The International Monetary Fund and ADB projected growth of 5.1% in 2017 while the World Bank projected growth 
of 5.2% for 2017.

2 
5.  Against this backdrop of slower economic growth, the government is finding it difficult to 
reverse the trend of rising income inequality. Since 2000, Indonesia has experienced one of the 
largest increases in household income inequality in Southeast Asia. The Gini coefficient, which 
measures a country’s household income inequality, increased from 0.30 in 2000 to 0.39 in 2016. 
Inequality is closely connected to poverty, especially in rural areas, where 62.2% of the poor 
reside. Moreover, while 10.7% of the population lives below the poverty line, about 40.0% of all 
people remain clustered around the national poverty line.3 Significant improvement is required to 
meet the government’s Gini coefficient target of 0.36 by 2019. Literature shows that financial 
exclusion is directly related to inequality.4 This is because financial exclusion deprives the poor 
of opportunities to raise incomes through savings and pensions and mitigate financial risks arising 
from natural disasters and economic shocks. Other factors affecting inequality include unequal 
access to education, jobs, public services and inefficient redistributive policies. 
 
6.  In Indonesia, financial exclusion of a large share of the adult population is a problem. 
Based on data from the 2015 Global Findex, only 36% of the Indonesian adult population has a 
formal bank account (Figure 1). This compares unfavorably with Malaysia and Thailand, where 
over 75% of the population has a bank account. Similarly, the share of the adult population with 
access to formal credit is relatively low in Indonesia. Only 13% of the adult population in Indonesia 
has a loan from a formal financial institution compared with 20% in Malaysia. Access to bank 
accounts by the poorest 40% of people is 22%, which is also significantly lower than in Malaysia 
and Thailand. Access to accounts by women is also low at 37% compared with 75% in Thailand.5 
 
Figure 1: Financial Inclusion in Indonesia and Selected Countries in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
 
Source: Global FinDex 2015. 
   
7.  A developed and stable financial system safeguards the inclusiveness of the financial 
system and has a positive effect on reducing inequality and poverty.6 Financial instability can 
adversely affect businesses, reduce job opportunities and credit availability, and raise the cost of 
finance. This particularly affects the poor and vulnerable as access to finance is an important 
coping strategy for them to deal with economic and financial uncertainties. The establishment of 
                                                
3  Data from National Statistics Office of Indonesia, https://www.bps.go.id/. 
4  International Monetary Fund. 2015. Causes of Income Inequality: A Global Perspective. Washington, DC. 
5  Sector Assessment (Summary): Finance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
6  International Monetary Fund. 2016. Financial Development, Inequality, and Poverty:  Washington, DC.

3 
the OJK as a unified regulator is the first step to develop the finance sector and promote stability 
in an integrated manner. Financial stability is legally a joint responsibility between the OJK, Bank 
Indonesia, Ministry of Finance and the Deposit Insurance Commission. The separation of roles 
between the OJK and Bank Indonesia is clear.7 The OJK exercises micro prudential supervisory 
powers whereas Bank Indonesia oversees macro prudential surveillance, monetary policy and 
the payment system.  These institutional reforms have improved financial stability. As of February 
2017, Indonesia’s senior 5-year credit default swap, which is used as a proxy for financial system 
risk, improved to 140 basis points compared with 280 basis points in September 2015.8 However, 
downside risks to stability still exist, as nonperforming loans and corporate external debt exposure 
have marginally increased. In addition, Indonesia’s shallow domestic capital market can make the 
finance sector susceptible to heightened market volatility and vulnerable to the risk of sudden 
capital outflow. In addition, despite efforts to deepen the market, Indonesia’s finance sector 
remains largely bank based and is relatively small. In 2016, finance sector assets (bank credit, 
market capitalization, and bonds) represented 105% of gross domestic product, compared with 
about 175% for the Philippines; 179% for Viet Nam; and over 300% for Malaysia and Thailand. 
 
8.  Binding constraints. The government has recognized the challenges it needs to address 
to have a stable, developed, and inclusive finance sector. They are (i) the incomplete framework 
and coordination mechanism for financial stability, (ii) the shallow finance sector, and (iii) financial 
exclusion. These constraints are discussed in paras. 9–11.  
 
9.  Incomplete  framework  and  coordination  mechanism  for  financial  stability.  A 
comprehensive  regulatory  framework  and  operational  coordinating  mechanism  underpin 
prudential  supervision  and  financial  stability.  Four  main  impediments  affect  this.  First, 
notwithstanding the setting up of the OJK as a unified regulator, the organization and reporting 
structure of the OJK still mirrors that of the former regulators with each subsector reporting directly 
to a chief executive. This is reflected in the practice of each subsector having its own blueprint or 
plan which at times does not consider developments in other subsectors. In addition, the capacity 
of the regulators of each sector is uneven, which complicates the adoption of a fully integrated 
approach to licensing, supervision, and information sharing. Second, the OJK’s operational 
independence requires it to be financially independent. The OJK should be able to operate based 
on levies collected from the industry. Until 2016, the government continued to partially fund OJK 
operations by allocating a total of Rp4.1 trillion from the 2014 and 2015 national budgets. Third, 
until recently the regulatory framework for financial stability did not provide the OJK with the 
authority to require systemic banks to increase capital to mitigate financial risks. In addition, 
regulators  and  supervisors  did  not  have  legal  immunity  from  prosecution,  which  impedes 
enforcement. Fourth, the coordination mechanism for financial stability was not institutionalized.  
 
10.  Shallow finance sector. The key challenge to deepening the finance sector is to develop 
a strong and credible finance sector, including Islamic finance, based on international standards 
and best practices. There is also a need to develop an enabling environment to develop the 
finance sector. There are three impediments to meeting these objectives. First, the regulatory 
framework for corporate governance of publicly listed companies takes a traditional prescriptive 
approach. This is not in line with international best practices which promote public disclosure of 
compliance with corporate governance. Provisions on conflict of interest and a whistleblowing 
system  also  require  strengthening  in  Indonesia.  Second,  the  government  and  the  OJK’s 
commitment to develop Islamic finance should be based on international best practices including 
in taxation and prudential standards. The capital gains tax imposed on all asset transfers hampers 
                                                
7  Regulatory Structure of Financial Sector Regulators (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).  
8  This is still high compared to the 70–90 basis points for Thailand and the Philippines.

4 
development of Islamic capital market, including for infrastructure financing as they require 
multiple asset transfers leading to doubling of capital gains tax. Thus, the tax framework is biased 
against Islamic capital market products. In Indonesia, the size of the corporate sukuk (Islamic 
financial certificate similar to corporate bond) market by the end of 2016 is only $900 million 
compared to $88 billion in Malaysia which has tax neutrality. Third, subnational governments are 
reluctant to issue municipal bonds because they are required to undergo audit processes from 
two auditors, which is costly. This duplication arises because of conflicting laws. The local 
government law requires subnational governments to be audited by the Supreme Audit Board, 
whereas the capital market law only accepts audits by private auditors registered with the OJK. 
Other constraints include inadequate accounting and reporting guidelines for the repo market.9  
 
11.  Financial exclusion. Inadequate financial literacy and incomplete consumer protection 
have contributed to a large share of the adult population being excluded from the finance sector. 
Microfinance in Indonesia has the potential to increase access to finance in remote areas but 
requires  close supervision from the OJK  and structured  capacity  building for the  industry. 
Branchless banking, where agents are contracted locally amongst the community to offer financial 
products, is also promising but for now is heavily focused in the more developed regions of Java. 
Furthermore, the 2016 OJK financial inclusion and literacy survey shows that literacy amongst 
women (26%) is lower than men (33%) and the national average (29%). The survey also shows 
large regional disparities in financial literacy among the population. For example, financial literacy 
rates of the adult population in Jakarta (40.0%) and West Java (38.7%) are far higher than in 
West Papua (19.3%). There is a need for the OJK to develop literacy programs that better target 
the  population,  including  school  students,  women  and  poorer  income  regions.  Incomplete 
consumer protection also contributes to financial exclusion. The establishment of the Securities 
Investor Protection Fund (SIPF) is a step in the right direction. However, the number of financial 
intermediaries covered by the fund is limited and the amount of coverage provided to investors 
inadequate. Similarly, alternative dispute resolution, which provides investors relief from lengthy 
court processes, is promising but must cover all subsectors and operate efficiently. 
 
12.  Government reform agenda. Indonesia’s National Medium-Term Development Plan for 
2015–2019 (RPJMN) seeks to promote “growth with equity” by reducing the Gini coefficient to 
0.36 and lowering the poverty rate to 7%–8% by 2019. The government recognizes that promoting 
financial stability, developing the financial market, and improving access to financial services for 
the poor are integral to meeting these targets. The government’s strategy consists of a series of 
reforms—starting with implementing the OJK’s mandate as an independent and unified regulator, 
developing a regulatory framework, and implementing crisis management protocols for financial 
stability, followed by measures to develop the capital market and a stronger focus on financial 
inclusion. In addition to the RPJMN, the government also launched the National Financial 
Inclusion Strategy in August 2016, which sets an ambitious target for 75% of the adult population 
to have access to financial services by 2019. Also, launched in 2016, and with ADB assistance, 
is the OJK’s consolidated Financial Sector Master Plan, 2015-2019, which includes 411 reforms 
and programs, 134 of which are considered priority.   
 
13.  ADB’s experience. ADB has had a long-term engagement with the government on 
finance sector development, recognizing that finance sector reforms are sequential and long term. 
One of the most significant finance sector reforms has been the creation of the OJK as a unified 
and independent regulator in 2012 which can be traced back to ADB’s assistance in 1999. 
Between 1999 and 2012, ADB provided consistent support through six major finance sector

5 
operations (Figure 2). This started with the Financial Governance and Social Security Reform 
Program of 2002, supporting the implementation of nonbank finance sector reform, designing the 
OJK, and amending relevant laws and regulations.This was followed by ADB’s capital market 
 
development  program  and  technical  assistance  (TA)  grant  in  2007,  which  focused  on 
strengthening market surveillance and investor protection. The OJK Law was enacted in 2011, 
and the OJK started implementing its mandate to regulate the capital market and nonbank 
financial institutions in December 2012. The initial focus on the capital market and nonbank 
financial institutions was supported by ADB’s Financial Market Development and Integration 
Program (FMDIP), approved in 2012, and associated TA projects. After the establishment of the 
OJK, ADB continued to support the government and the OJK through the approval of the FMDIP 
cluster and subprogram 1 in 2015 (footnote 1). Through the FMDIP, ADB’s initial focus was to 
support (i) the OJK to implement its mandate including developing the technical and regulatory 
capacities for an independent and unified regulator, and (ii) the government to develop and 
coordinate finance  sector  policies through the  Center  of Financial  Sector  Policies  (PKSK). 
Subprogram 2 broadens ADB’s areas of engagement to include financial inclusion reforms. The 
FMDIP complements ADB’s other programs on investment climate and public finance linked to 
sustainable development goals.10  
 
14.  Lessons from the experience. ADB’s experience provided three lessons that were 
incorporated into the program. First, developing the legal structure for an integrated regulator is 
just the first step. The OJK needs extensive support, particularly to develop subsectors with 
weaker capacities, as a prerequisite for effective integrated supervision. Hence the FMDIP’s 
support  in  capital  market  and  nonbank  financial  institutions  subsectors.  Second,  reducing 
inequality requires a comprehensive approach including reforming social assistance programs, 
improving the investment climate, and financial inclusion. Third, financial inclusion reforms should 
be holistic and require complementary reforms in enhancing access to financial services, financial 
literacy, consumer protection, and using financial technology.  
 
15.  ADB’s value addition to program design and implementation. ADB approved a policy 
advisory TA in 2015 to support key reforms that underpin reforms in subprogram 2 of the FMDIP.11 
The TA supported reforms in all three outputs covering financial stability, development, and 
inclusion. The TA also supported PKSK in the Ministry of Finance with capacity development and 
policy advisory services. Separate TA was mobilized to support local government reforms, 
including capacity building and shadow issuances for municipal bonds.12 In addition, regional TA 
on capital market integration supported the OJK to adopt best practices in corporate governance 
based on the Association of Southeast Asian Nations Corporate Governance Scorecard.13  
 
16.  The results from this assistance have been impressive. The Law on Prevention and 
Resolution of Financial System Crisis enacted in 2016 is a significant landmark for financial 
stability. The law provides legal immunity for supervisors who perform their duties in good faith. 
The law also provides criteria for designating systemically important banks and reinforces risk-

based supervision. At the same time, the OJK became fiscally autonomous. With ADB assistance, 
the OJK launched the consolidated finance sector master plan in January 2016, which prescribes 
key finance sector reforms. The OJK has set up a cross-sector team to monitor implementation 
of the master plan. The government is also developing a tax neutrality framework for Islamic 
capital market products to attract more foreign investments especially for infrastructure.  In 
financial inclusion, the OJK launched the International Center for Microfinance and Financial 
Inclusion which now provides capacity building programs to the industry. The OJK also expanded 
the number of investors to 654,389 (assets of Rp3,569 trillion) protected under the SIPF. Finally, 
the OJK increased the number of banks participating in branchless banking from four to 16 and 
now covers 106,490 agents in 499 districts.

17.  Development partner coordination. Close coordination between ADB, the International 
Monetary  Fund,  the  World  Bank,  and  other  development  partners  has  created  strong 
programmatic synergies in the finance sector. Coordination is demonstrated by ADB’s support to 
implement  selected  recommendations  from  the  Financial  Sector  Assessment  Program. 
Coordination for the FMDIP is based on the government’s process through PKSK. Jointly with the 
World Bank, ADB supports the Coordinating Ministry of Economic Affairs, which chairs the 
secretariat for financial inclusion in the National Council. Development partners provide support 
to working groups in the council. The financial inclusion division of the PKSK, which ADB supports, 
leads the working group on policies and regulations.14  
 
18.  Economic impact of the program. The three outputs of the program combined are 
expected to lead to increased development and inclusiveness of the finance sector. The potential 
economic gains, including lower cost of government borrowing, are to be achieved through (i) 
strengthening the regulatory structure for financial stability, (ii) deepening the financial market, 
and (iii) enhancing financial inclusion (para. 31).  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
19.  The impact will be increased annual growth rate of the finance sector in alignment with the 
RPJMN, 2015–2019. The outcome will be increased development and inclusiveness of the 
                                                
14 Development Coordination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

7 
finance sector. At the inception of the programmatic approach in 2014, the government agreed to 
accomplish seven expected prior actions (or triggers) and 18 policy milestones as a basis for 
subprogram  2. 15  All  seven  prior  actions  have  been  accomplished,  with  four  exceeding 
expectations. During processing of subprogram 2, a new prior action on financial literacy was 
added and the policy milestone on the law on crisis prevention was upgraded to a prior action to 
advance reforms in this area.  
 
20.  At the government’s request, ADB agreed to refine some policy milestones with the aim 
of streamlining the policy matrix. Four of these milestones are now merged into two policy actions 
as  they  were  related  to  similar  complementary  reforms.  One  new  milestone  on  financial 
technology was added, and one policy milestone was shifted to subprogram 3 and replaced with 
a milestone reflecting changes in legislative priority. Subprogram 2 still contains 25 reform actions 
(9 expected prior actions representing high-impact reforms and 16 policy milestones), which the 
government and the OJK accomplished in advance during July 2015–March 2017. The changes 
in the policy matrix are reflected in the revised design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
Subprogram 3 will include 10 prior actions and 12 policy milestones. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
21.  Output 1: Regulatory structure for financial stability strengthened. This output builds 
on accomplishments in subprogram 1 to establish the OJK’s integrated supervisory framework 
and strengthen the coordination mechanism for financial stability. There were 4 accomplishments 
in subprogram 2. First, the government enacted in 2016 the Law on Prevention and Resolution of 
Financial System Crisis that provides the OJK with powers to increase capital for systemic banks 
to mitigate financial crisis and provides regulators with legal immunity. Second, the OJK achieved 
full operational fiscal autonomy. Through the implementation of its revenue-raising powers, the 
OJK collected $337 million of levies from the industry, allowing full operational cost recovery. 
Third, in 2016, the OJK also launched its first ever integrated finance sector master plan, 2015–
2019. The plan consists of 411 actions and programs covering banking, capital market and non- 
bank financial institutions. A coordinating and monitoring framework has been put in place, and 
the monitoring committee provides regular updates on implementation. As of November 2016, the 
OJK had completed 69 programs and actions including simplification of rules for issuances of 
financial products. Fourth, an integrated information-technology-based licensing system was 
implemented which harmonizes the licensing interface for all intermediaries. 
 
22.  For subprogram 3, the government and the OJK will develop regulations to implement the 
Law on Financial System Crisis Prevention and Management. The OJK will also continue 
implementing  the  master  plan  with  regular  reporting.  The  authority  is  also  committed  to 
implementing a transparent levy system and cross-sector consolidated supervision.   
 
23.  Output 2: Financial market deepened. This output supports the government’s reforms 
to deepen the financial market by adopting international standards and creating an enabling 
environment  for  financial  services  and  products.  There  are  five  major  accomplishments  in 
subprogram 2. First, the OJK adopted the “comply or explain” approach to corporate governance 
with a shift away from prescriptive regulations toward more public financial disclosure. Second, 
the OJK continued to implement standards of the Islamic Financial Services Board related to 
governance and Islamic collective investment schemes. Third, the government prepared the tax 
neutrality  framework  for  Islamic  capital  market  products.  Fourth,  to  create  an  enabling

8 
environment for the financial sector, the OJK strengthened risk management of insurance and 
reinsurance  companies,  including  requiring  higher  capital  provisioning.  Fifth,  the  OJK  also 
prepared a framework for accepting audits on municipal issuances by the Supreme Audit Board 
and accounting guidelines for repo.  
 
24.  For subprogram 3, the OJK will continue to facilitate the pilot issuance of municipal bonds 
with the view of having the first issuance by 2019. In Islamic finance, the OJK will continue to 
implement at least 50% of standards issued by the Islamic Financial Services Board and the 
government will issue regulations on tax neutrality for Islamic capital market products.  
 
25.  Output 3: Financial inclusion enhanced. This output aims to promote financial inclusion 
through improving poor households’ access to financial services and products, financial literacy, 
and consumer protection. There were six major accomplishments in subprogram 2 under this 
output. First, on improving access of the poor to financial services, the OJK set up the International 
Center for Microfinance and Financial Inclusion to build industry capacity in microfinance and 
financial inclusion. ADB and the center jointly published the Indonesia Microfinance Overview in 
2015, which provides recommendations for expanding financial inclusion and necessary financial 
services for women residing in poor households. Second, the OJK also expanded the number 
and geographical coverage of branchless banks from 4 to 16 banks, covering 106,490 agents in 
499 cities and/or districts. This reform is particularly relevant to women since it brings the provision 
of financial services closer to their homes. Third, the government established the National Council 
for Financial Inclusion chaired by the President of Indonesia. The council’s mandate is to address 
implementation bottlenecks, coordinate financial inclusion initiatives, and monitor and evaluate 
implementation of the national strategy. The strategy makes specific reference to women and 
micro and small enterprises. Fourth, on financial literacy, the OJK collaborated with the Ministry 
of Education to publish books targeting students of various levels and those visually impaired. 
Fifth, the OJK also implemented a range of financial education initiatives, including focus group 
discussions with women, and developed mobile applications on financial literacy to improve 
outreach. Sixth, on consumer protection, the SIPF was expanded to include custodian banks, 
which increased the number of protected investors by 165,048 individuals. This complements 
existing protection for the banking sector through the Deposit Insurance Commission. 
 
26.  For subprogram 3, the OJK will continue to leverage information and communication 
technology by developing self-learning e-modules to expand its financial literacy programs. 
Access of branchless banking will also be expanded and data collection improved to include 
gender data for agents and customers.  
 
D.    Development Financing Needs 
 
27.  The government has requested a policy-based loan of $400 million from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources to help finance subprogram 2. The loan will have a 15-year term, including a 
grace period of 3 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a commitment charge of 0.15% per year; 
and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. Based on this, the 
average loan maturity is 9.25 years, and there is no maturity premium payable to ADB. The 
proceeds of the policy-based loan will be disbursed to Indonesia in accordance with ADB’s Loan 
Disbursement Handbook (2015, as amended from time to time). 
 
28.  The gross financing need is $48.7 billion, with a budget deficit of 2.4% of gross domestic 
product. To finance the deficit, the government planned to raise $44.9 billion from the issuance of 
securities and $3.8 billion from official foreign loans. The size of subprogram 2 primarily reflects

9 
the government’s financing needs, the strength of the reform program, and the development 
expenditures arising from the program, such as operational costs for the PKSK, implementation 
of best practices for Islamic finance and other institutional reforms, and costs associated with 
financial literacy programs (para. 31).  
 
E.    Implementation Arrangements 
 
29.  The implementation period for subprogram 2 is from July 2015 to March 2017 and 
subprogram 3 will be implemented from April 2017 to April 2019. The Fiscal Policy Agency in the 
Ministry of Finance is the executing agency while the OJK is the implementing agency. The PKSK 
will, in coordination with the International Department of the OJK, monitor the implementation of 
the policy actions under the policy matrix.  
 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
30.  Subprogram 2 has attached TA (Promoting Innovative Financial Inclusion) supporting the 
government and the OJK to advance the financial inclusion agenda through three outputs: (i) 
increased access to finance through innovative approaches, (ii) broadened financial literacy, and 
(iii) enhanced consumer protection.16 Under the TA, a pilot project will be implemented to deepen 
financial  inclusion,  complementing  the  government’s  digital  government-to-person  payment 
initiative. The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of office space, equipment, staff resources, and other in-
kind contributions. The Fiscal Policy Agency will be the executing agency and the OJK will be the 
implementing agency. The implementation period of the TA will be June 2017 to June 2019. 
 
IV. DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
 
31.  The program impact assessment estimates potential net benefits of the program to be 
about  $5.9  billion  in  present  value.17 The  benefits  of  financial  inclusion  are  estimated  at 
approximately $3.4 billion, which includes $145 million through higher levels of saving by the poor, 
$2.4 billion through better access to capital for small and medium-sized enterprises and women, 
and efficiency gains of approximately $830 million through the branchless banking initiative. The 
total cost to the economy is approximately $913 million. Approximately half of this amount is a 
cost to the industry through the OJK’s levy. This approach shifts the tax burden from taxpayers to 
the industry and frees up fiscal space in the national budget. Other costs include financial literacy 
outreach programs to women and micro and small enterprises. 
 
B.  Governance 
 
32.  The government has made progress in improving the legal and regulatory framework for 
public financial management. Since the enactment of laws on state finance, state treasury, and 
state audit in 2003–2004, most regulations for these laws have been promulgated. In 2012, the 
number of government agencies that received an unqualified audit opinion from the external audit 
agency increased to 65% (from about 40% in 2009). ADB has reinforced this momentum with 
                                                
16 Attached Technical Assistance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
17 Program Impact Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
continuing support to improve technical capacity on state audit. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy 
(1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the government. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
 
33.  Subprogram 2 is categorized as effective gender mainstreaming at entry. One of the key 
components of the program concerns enhancing financial inclusion and ensuring improved 
access to finance for the poor, unbanked, and micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises. The 
Global Findex data show that a similar percentage of women and men saved at a financial 
institution in 2013, and 15% of the total male population and 11% of the total female population 
borrowed from a financial institution. Women entrepreneurs face unique challenges because of 
limitations in time, mobility, and resources. Hence, there is a need to pay special attention to 
ensuring increased access to financial products and services for women entrepreneurs. One of 
the key gender related targets in subprogram 2 is financial literacy initiatives for women.   
 
D.    Safeguards 
 
34.  The program does not trigger ADB’s safeguard policies and is classified category C for 
impacts on the environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. 
 
E.    Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
35.  The program faces only one substantial risk, which is lack of coordination for financial 
inclusion reform. The National Council for Financial Inclusion is a critical reform but there is risk 
of slow implementation and stakeholders not extending the fullest cooperation, especially in the 
initial stages. Mitigation measures include ADB supporting the PKSK and the OJK as key 
agencies in the National Council. The risk assessment for the FMDIP is medium.18  
 
IV. ASSURANCES 
 
36.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the program shall conform to 
all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the loan 
documents. 
 
V. RECOMMENDATION 
 
37.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based loan would comply with the Articles of 
agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
loan of $400,000,000 to the Republic of Indonesia for subprogram 2 of the Financial Market 
Development and Inclusion Program, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in regular terms, 
with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility; for a term of 15 years, including a grace period of 3 years; and such other 
terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
agreement presented to the Board. 
 
                    Takehiko Nakao
